title: CSF.1
text: The student will
subject: Computer Science
subs: compare the structures, functions, and interactions between application software, system software, and hardware; and
explore the relationship between hardware and software using the Internet of Things.

title: CSF.2
text: The student will model how information is broken down into smaller pieces, transmitted as packets through multiple devices over networks and the Internet, and reassembled at the destination.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.3
text: The student will explain the role of protocols in transmitting data across networks and the Internet.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.4
text: The student will evaluate the scalability and reliability of networks, by describing the relationship between routers, switches, servers, topology, and addressing.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.5
text: The student will identify and explain ways that sensitive data (assets) can be threatened by malware and other computer attacks, using appropriate terminology.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.6
text: The student will give examples of ways to protect sensitive data (assets) from malware and other computer attacks and evaluate them according to multiple criteria.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.7
text: The student will explain typical tradeoffs between usability and security and recommend security measures in a given scenario based on these (or other) tradeoffs.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.8
text: The student will write or adapt a program to validate its input and to avoid certain kinds of vulnerabilities.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.9
text: The student will evaluate the tradeoffs in how data elements are organized and where data is stored.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.10
text: The student will create interactive data visualizations using software tools to help others better understand real-world phenomena.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.11
text: The student will use data analysis tools and techniques to identify patterns in data representing complex systems.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.12
text: The student will develop a program working individually and in teams using a text- based language.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.13
text: The student will identify the expected output of a program given a problem and some input.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.14
text: The student will design and iteratively develop programs for practical intent or personal expression, incorporating feedback from users.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.15
text: The student will design and implement algorithms using
subject: Computer Science
subs: sequencing of instructions;
conditional execution; and
iteration.

title: CSF.16
text: The student will implement a program that accepts input values, stores them in appropriately named variables, and produces output.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.17
text: The student will trace the execution of an algorithm, illustrating output and changes in values of named variables.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.18
text: The student will apply the basic operations used with numeric and non-numeric data types in developing programs.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.19
text: The student will use predefined functions to simplify the solution of a complex problem.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.20
text: The student will apply simple algorithms to a collection of data.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.21
text: The student will create programs
subject: Computer Science
subs: demonstrating an understanding that program development is an ongoing process that requires adjusting and debugging along the way; and
using version control to create and refine programs.

title: CSF.22
text: The student will use tools and methods for collaboration on a project to increase connectivity of people in different cultures and career fields.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.23
text: The student will evaluate the ways computing impacts personal, ethical, social, economic, and cultural practices.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.24
text: The student will explain the beneficial and harmful effects that intellectual property laws can have on innovation, including the impact of open source software.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSF.25
text: The student will explain the privacy concerns related to the collection and generation of data through automated processes that are not always evident to users.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.1
text: The student will develop and apply criteria for evaluating a computer system for a given purpose.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.2
text: The student will illustrate ways computing systems implement logic, input, and output through hardware components.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.3
text: The student will explain abstractions enabling
subject: Computer Science
subs: one computer to communicate with another over an Internet connection; and
different layers of Internet technology to build on one another.

title: CSP.4
text: The student will explain design principles enabling large-scale operation of the Internet to connect devices and networks all over the world.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.5
text: The student will explain symmetric and asymmetric encryption as they pertain to messages being sent on a network.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.6
text: The student will discuss the methods and tradeoffs of collecting and analyzing data elements on a large scale.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.7
text: The student will select data collection tools and techniques to generate data sets that support a claim or communicate information. Implement a relational database to work with data.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.8
text: The student will discuss how data representations can be interpreted in a variety of forms, convert between data representations, and analyze the representation tradeoffs among various forms of digital information.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.9
text: The student will design and implement algorithms with
subject: Computer Science
subs: compound conditional execution; and
a variety of loop control structures.

title: CSP.10
text: The student will solve a complex problem by decomposing it into subtasks consisting of predefined functions and user-defined functions.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.11
text: The student will store, process, and manipulate data contained in a data structure.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.12
text: The student will systematically debug a program using an appropriate set of data.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.13
text: The student will explain how computing has impacted innovations in other fields positively and negatively, and enables collaboration between a variety of people.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.14
text: The student will evaluate the impact of equity, access, and influence on the distribution of computing resources in a global society, including the impacts of cloud computing.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.15
text: The student will explain how intellectual property concerns affect the tools for and products of computing, including combining existing content to create new artifacts and the impact of open source and free software.
subject: Computer Science

title: CSP.16
text: The student will evaluate the social and economic implications of privacy in the context of safety, law, or ethics.
subject: Computer Science

title: DS.1
text: The student will identify specific examples of real-world problems that can be effectively addressed using data science.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.2
text: The student will be able to formulate a top down plan for data collection and analysis, with quantifiable results, based on the context of a problem.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.3
text: The student will recognize the importance of data literacy and develop an awareness of how the analysis of data can be used in problem solving to effect change and create innovative solutions.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.4
text: The student will be able to identify data biases in the data collection process, and understand the implications and privacy issues surrounding data collection and processing.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.5
text: The student will use storytelling as a strategy to effectively communicate with data.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.6
text: The student will justify the design, use, and effectiveness of different forms of data visualizations.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.7
text: The student will be able to assess reliability of source data in preparation for mathematical modeling.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.8
text: The student will be able to acquire and prepare big data sets for modeling and analysis.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.9
text: The student will select and analyze data models to make predictions, while assessing accuracy and sources of uncertainty.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.10
text: The student will be able to summarize and interpret data represented in both conventional and emerging visualizations.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.11
text: The student will select statistical models and use goodness of fit testing to extract actionable knowledge directly from data.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.12
text: The student will be able to select and utilize appropriate technological tools and functions within those tools to process and prepare data for analysis.
subject: Data Science

title: DS.13
text: The student will be able to select and utilize appropriate technological tools and functions within those tools to analyze and communicate data effectively.
subject: Data Science

title: PRG.1
text: The student will describe and use best practices of program development that make some common flaws less likely and explain how this improves computer security.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.2
text: The student will create programs that model the relationships among different elements in collections of real-world data.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.3
text: The student will translate numbers between machine representations and human-accessible representations.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.4
text: The student will design and implement a program working individually and in teams using a text-based language.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.5
text: The student will explain the software life cycle and how it applies to iterative development processes.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.6
text: The student will design and implement an algorithm
subject: Computer Science
subs: with compound conditional execution, and analyze and evaluate complex Boolean conditions; and
using complex iteration, including nested loops

title: PRG.7
text: The student will implement programs that accept input from a variety of sources and produce output based on that input.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.8
text: The student will trace the execution of iterative and recursive algorithms, illustrating output and changes in values of named variables.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.9
text: The student will perform complex computations
subject: Computer Science
subs: on numbers, including modular division and random number generation; and
on strings, including substring manipulation and processing individual characters.

title: PRG.10
text: The student will demonstrate an understanding of different data types by using appropriate constructs to convert between them when appropriate.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.11
text: The student will analyze a large-scale computational problem, identify generalizable patterns, and implement a solution.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.12
text: The student will implement an algorithm that uses existing functions and accesses existing libraries or APIs to satisfy its requirements.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.13
text: The student will write functions, both with and without parameters, and both with and without return values, that represent abstractions useful to the solution of a larger problem.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.14
text: The student will create programs demonstrating an understanding of the interactions between classes in object-oriented design, and by implementing classes with instance data and methods to satisfy a design specification.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.15
text: The student will use code written by others by reading the documentation and incorporating it into their programs using proper citation of the reused code.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.16
text: The student will read and store data in 1D and 2D collections, and design and implement algorithms to process and manipulate those collections.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.17
text: The student will adapt classic algorithms for use in a particular context and analyze them for effectiveness and efficiency.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.18
text: The student will develop and use a series of test cases to verify that a program performs according to its design specifications, including edge cases and all branches.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.19
text: The student will, through the process of code review, evaluate a program's correctness, readability, usability, and other factors.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.20
text: The student will use a systematic approach and debugging tools to independently debug a program.
subject: Computer Science

title: PRG.21
text: The student will identify some of the practical, business, and ethical impacts of open source and free software and the widespread access they provide.
subject: Computer Science
